I want to get something out of the way first. I HAVE PLAYED THIS GAME MUCH LONGER THAN THE STEAM PLAYTIME.

Like another reviewer said, this is like a cross between FTL and Jules Verne. Lead a famous explorer (and his/her hired help) through strange new lands to meet (and potentially anger) the natives, battle wild animals and find enough treasure to gain the fame you need to become the greatest explorer the world has ever known.

The map is procedurally so you're going to have a new adventure every time, and the pixel artwork is really charming. In order to survive all six expeditions, you need to make sure you have all the right tools (rope, torches, food, etc) for the job, but you also need room in your inventory to fit all the fabulous treasure you've discovered. It's a fine balancing act between survival and fame/fortune.

Like all rogue-likes, lots of very bad things can happen to you. Shrines that hold the treasures could contain some nasty booby traps, like ever-widening chasms, or the great ball of nothingness, so do you risk getting that sold gold llama statue and thus potentially incur the wrath of the natives/deity/whatever? You won't know what will happen until you take it! Take care of your sanity meter and don't let it get to zero, or bad stuff will definitely happen to you. Crewmembers may fight, turn cannibal or wander off into the dark, never to be seen again.

I've been playing this game since Alpha 10 and even in Alpha status this game is 100% playable and nothing feels 'missing.' The devs have put out numerous additions and bugs every few weeks and this is one of the best rogue-likes I've ever played. It's a very unique spin on the genre, taking place in the 19th century as opposed to generic dungeons and space travels. You're going to feel like you're Indy as you play, except there's no Nazis. Have you got what it takes to become the greatest explorer?

An absolutely brilliant little rogulike - I adore this game. The atmosphere brilliantly captures a sense of exploration, and the fear sets in when sanity gets low too. The graphics are smart and suit the game well. The music is genuinely brilliant. The multiple expeditions format nicely breaks things into easy parts. The balancing of fame vs income works as beautifully as the scrap in FTL. So much of this game is already brilliant.

On the downside, combat is still a little unintuitive, and there may be some balance issues with some of followers - the artist needs a buff to offset all the inventory they take up. Also, some of the events are poorly balanced - right now, exploring caves is completely pointless, because it seems to outright kill max level companions the majority of the time. A bit more variety in the early expeditions would be appreciated too - right now, it's just a case of 100% the first expedition to rush on to something more interesting.

Overall, thoroughly recommended.

An extremely impressive game for being in Early Access. That said, there is so much more to be added to the game as well. The Curious Expedition caught my eye while I was looking for a game somewhat similar to Sunless Sea. That is, an adventure game that bases itself primarly on text. What I found was a great mixture of that and old school RPGs.

The game itself is played by selecting a character (based on historical figures) whom has his/her own traits, followers, and starter gear. This selection ultimately determines your playstyle. You will visit various locations while competing with several other adventurers to bring back the most impressive artifacts and native items. There is also a kind of bonus you can complete if agreed upon before leaving.
Ex. 1. A priest asks if you would help him spread the word of God in a certain village.
2. A commander asks you to bring back a soldier who is AWOL.

There are are also many interesting mechanics such as a 'Sanity' Bar which determines your movement across the hex-like board of the land. There are deserts, jungles, mountains, and other terrains to trek across, each with their own dangers and rewards depending on what region you're exploring. When on an expedition, the further into the map you go, the more will be revealed.

Things will can very interesting, very fast once you choose to steal that idol the Natives worship. Sometimes natural or...un-natural disasters can occur sending you scrambling across the board in panic. Your adventure ends when you find the Golden Pyramid in each area you visit. However, you may stay as long as possible if you wish to collect more artifacts and such. These can be sold or donated to the musuem for fame at the end of each expedition.

Verdict: - 7.5/10 EARLY ACCESS RATING
The Curious Expedition is very impressive, especially for an Early Access game. It is fair to say that whatever content is put into this game when its full release occurs will only make the game that much better. Any fans of Adventure games or even RPG fans will find that this is actually a very nice change from the norm. There are many choices and consequences that will affect your story, ranging from minor to catastrophic. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loved Sunless Sea (although this game is not as dark) or anyone that is seeking an adventure game that is focused mainly on text. The music in the game is also pretty cool.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has some roguelike randomness, pixel art, and can be completed in about an hour if you know what you are doing.  You play as an explorer from a romanticised nineteenth century, choosing from about a dozen historical names with different special abilities.

You start with a random kit of companions and or donkeys to make a party and set off on an expedition to gain fame and fortune.  You must complete six expeditions and beat an arbitrary fame score of AI rivals who you don't interact with.  Each expedition creates a random map which gets larger and more dangerous with each successful expedition.  There are villages and shrines to discover, wild beasts to dodge or slay and wonders both natural and supernatural.  Of course, all abstracted into some tidy icons and statuses.  Combat is a simple and fun turn based system of dice rolling and re-rolling to create combos a la Yahtzee.  The goal of each expedition is to find and enter the gold pyramid somewhere on the map, but you'll want to be carrying some loot before you enter as the pyramid magically ends the expedition and sends you back to the Explorer's club in England.  You'll be able to pick a new perk for your explorer from a randomised three choices.  Then you can cash in each piece of loot for either Fame points or Funds to finance the next expedition.

You'll receive a random quest and be able to shop from a meagre shop whose stores are you guessed it, randomised.  You'll have to adapt to what the game gives you if you want to steer this this baby through to the final expedition.  But, the game is short.  Mistakes are usually costly and often fatal but you aren't deeply invested because it's not an epic game.  Good fun, but currently lacking depth in this Alpha stage.  Still good enuff that I feel I'm going to get my money's worth.

~Meadow's Review~
As of this review, I've played this 10 hours and yet to finish off one entire episode of all 6 successful expeditions. Although I repeatedly came to 6/6 I never got till the end =( anyway! And remember it's Early Access!

So far it is a bugfree experience into the Alpha game with a skinny, but raw experience. There's plenty of RNG and roguelikeness in this game. Although it could use more features, with the 10 hours I've spent so far I've yet to become truly bored of it with many events, predators and so forth haunting my poor expedition that just wants to find and chart the Golden Pyramid.

In the game itself, there is plenty to discover and try to keep yourself sane. By consuming mangoes, cocoa leaves, drink some whiskey etc. If you have a cook, you can cook raw meat you get from trading or hunting animals as well.

I was also pleasantly surprised that the loot I found during my expedition could be brought back or traded during the expedition for helpful items. Upon bringing them back however, you can trade them for fame to win against your competitor intrepid adventurers or if you feel confident enough or need the cash, turn them in the auctioneer for a fixed cash transaction. Maybe there should be a feature here too in the future that you could really 'auction' them and see if the NPC can bid on them for a higher/lower price? Definitely can use more features.

I found that you could only have 5 party members however, and that a pack animal counts towards the number limit. And you can only have so many items with you at one time. This can be increased by leveling up your party members up to level 4. Although you cannot level up your animal nor can you level up the leader. Which I frown upon. There is an animal pack character though which upon leveling up increases the amount your pack animals can drag along. However, consider very carefully as that means one less effective combat unit which can be very deadly.

Unless you can keep running. Which you probably can't. Once you aggro any wild animal (red, not blue) they will try to follow you until they catch up to you, in which you will need to fight them off or flee. Fleeing has potential consequences however so choose wisely.

Positive features:
+ Fairly bugfree, despite this being an Alpha game at the moment of this review!
+ Active devs on forums as well as Twitter.
+ Unlockable characters after you achieve some special prerequisites!
+ Loot. And Gold. Did I mention massive Gold Statues?
+ Choice between turning them in for additional fame upon return towards Civilization or additional cash for future expeditions.
+ Can recruit helpful characters during or before travels. Max party size is 5.
+ Upon ending on successful expedition you can choose one perk to aid in future expeditions.

Some remarks:
= Some items in your inventory doesn't stack. This is especially true for loot. So that means you have to make a very weighted decision to drop down items that can be very useful towards you instead of loot. I especially found this a huge constraint during my travels.
= Cannot level up beyond 4. Maybe that is due balancing issues?
= Gameplay is alright for an Alpha, I do expect more features as well as nice things in the future for this game.
= The game could be more clear with dice combinations, although I managed to figure out this myself by experimenting... This could be very frustrating for new players towards the game.
= Would like a bit more information about the location I choose to send an expedition from.
= Maybe a HUD or extended info panel/stash once you return from an expedition would be nice so you can adequately prepare for the next one or drop some things behind.
= Improving standings with the local tribes seems near impossible. I've never in all my playthroughs gotten near 20/20 yet. Highest was however 15/20 which I managed to unlock the last and in my opinion, hardest character with.

Negative aspects:
- Cannot upgrade pack animals, pets or leader. Unsure if intended feature or not.
- Seems there is no way to stop bleeding once it happens without a medi kit. Reminds me of TF2 when I bleed to death =(
- When you trigger certain events, it will become impossible to get near the Golden Pyramid, thereby with no ending button the only thing you can do is restart the game and start a new expedition.
- There is no way to pass time whilst stuck on one spot. (Dev commented on forum that a fix is pending)
- No additional info from the main expeditioneer's sidekicks when you start a new expedition. You don't know what their character info is therefore you have to jot it down somewhere if you want to make a weighted decision on which party to pick before you forget the info again for a new expedition.

Conclusion: If you value one €1 for every hour played, then this game is definitely worth it during their Alpha Access with plenty of potential and growth space. However there will be probably a long time to go before this game is finished, but this game is quite interesting and there was no moment when I got bored with the events in game and my desire to snatch every single golden statue!

This is a fantastic game, better and more functional than a lot of games I've bought that were already out of Alpha.  There's a reason why I've racked up nearly 200 hours on it already.

The devs, as near as I can tell, are great, and are active in the forums, both in terms of addressing reported bugs and in terms of participating in discussions regarding game balance and so forth, and incorporating the fruits of those discussions into future updates.  The one time I encountered a game-breaking bug, and reported it, it was hotfixed within 48 hours, which is incredible to me.  These folks are great.

The updates seem to come like clockwork every few weeks, too, which is awesome, because there are always new features and balance tweaks happening.  Really, this game could have been considered done when I bought it (in Alpha 11 or 12, I think), but they keep adding more cool stuff to it.  Dinosaurs, the Hall of Fame, being able to have your loot carried by a giant tortoise named Ms. Perkins.  What is not to love here?  I mean, come on.

If you enjoy Roguelikes, and are inclined to be darkly amused by Victorian exploration narratives, buy this game.  If you just like Roguelikes, buy this game.  Screw it, just buy this game.  Only $15 (US), and it keeps getting better every couple of weeks, and it's already really great now, while it's still in Alpha.

The game is absolutely fantastic. It is everything you think it is from the trailer. The game revolves around choosing an explorer (actual famous historical figures) and discovering uncharted lands. I really do wish they had more music.

My favorite part of the game is all the little things you discover throughout each playthrough. It seems the same everytime but with different characters, who only provide some inherent bonus, until you really start to pay attention. I just recently noticed all the dialogue in the game is written in the style of the person you are playing as, and after googling (every) explorers and learning about them this was a very, very nice touch that added more personality and life to the game. I also appreciated that the game did have a smattering of education, in that some of these historical figures I had never heard of.

Highly recommend, worth every penny.

I'm happy to report that my expedition team has died because of my own stupid mistakes rather than anything that the game has thrown at me.

It's worth an impulse buy for a few hours of entertainment, but I'm going to hold off on playing it again until the full product is released because the events can get (again, at this point in time) a little samey.

TLDR: I really love this game, it's probably one of my all time tops.

Curious Expedition is a seemingly simple take on a seemingly common genre: a survival exploration game with 2D pixel art. But as much as that sounds horrible and generic and flavor of the month, it's not at all.

There is a quote on the store page from a Rock Paper Shotgun article, that the game already has a lot to offer the player, even as an Early Access title. That's true, but that quote is from 2014 and currently two years and roughly 27 content updates ago.

Curious Expedition's first great success is that it's actually an *exploration* game. So many games featuring exploring are all about clicking nodes or collecting some sort of points or resources or whatever. reviewText:
Early Access Review

TCE is a procedural rogue-like exploration game that provides you with plenty of difficult but meaningful decisions to make as you lead a party on a series of dangerous and often ill-fated expeditions into uncharted territory. You'll meet natives, ransack shrines, explore caves, fight wild beasts, loot cool items, level up your party members, and occasionally eat those party members to survive.

If you're unable to see past the 16-bit style graphics to enjoy the epic adventurous narrative the games brilliant design allows you to create for yourself, TCE is probably not the game for you. But if you're a gamer's gamer, more concerned with making meaningful choices that could very well result in very tragic consequences, you'll find TCE refreshingly challenging.

Do you waste an inventory slot/funds on dynamite you may never use but will wish you had if you get trapped inside mountains?

Do you drink whiskey when getting low on sanity, even though your Scottish soldier is already and alcoholic and could only get worse?

Do you ransack the ancient altar to find loot, when you know it will upset your native animal handler who is giving your mounts a huge carrying bonus?

Do you explore that cave even though the cultist in your party has developed claustraphobia?

Do you rest overnight at that native village when your British soldier is an unapologeteic racist?

The answers to all of these questions are almost always yes. But you make these choices accepting the consequences, because the alternative is often far worse. And this is the brilliance of TCE and why I highly reccomend it.

Early Access Review

A great entertaining game!

It is still in alpha (11 as I'm writing this) but already very enjoyable and quit addictive.
You play a 19th century explorer heading out to six expeditions in a row to find the golden pyramid at the end of each expedition. On the way you loot and collect treasure, fight wild animals, natives or monsters and haggle with traders, natives or monsters... I mean slave traders. Between the expeditions treasure can be given to the museum for fame or sold to gain money for buying equipment for your next expedition.
An overview:
+ great atmosphere (you just have to love that nice retro pixel graphics)
+ dice roll combat system that is very fun with lots of dice combinations
+ surprising and fun events (transforming a jungle into a desert by accident or witnessing how one of your expedition members suddenly transforms into... something else)
+ recruit, dismiss and level your expedition members
+ management of items vs treasure, what to keep, what to toss?
+ great replay value because of many characters to choose from and random expeditions
+ great for playing in between, early expeditions take 5 to 10 minutes, later ones up to 30 minutes

Still in alpha, so the following issues will hopefully be addressed or fixed:
- many events are often very similar. A bit more diversity of hints and events would be nice
- very many texts and sometimes you click too fast and can't go back
- no chance to let time go on without moving (when trapped by rising water on one tile you can't do anything because time does not go on)
- you can only save between expeditions
- you can't sell or discard mundane items between missions
- too few combat combo opitions for the blue face dice
- sometimes the balance and difficulty in later missions is very frustrating (but developers promised to focus on this in the next patch)
- no record of your previous successes (or to be more accurate: failures)
- not much content when finishing the game (I believe a statue was mentioned?)

I have tons of fun playing this game and after 11 tries and 15 hours playtime I even managed to finish my sixth expedition, coming first, which was not so difficult, but surviving that's the hard part ^^'

I bought the game in late 2014, before it came to steam,  and it's a game I've come back to at least once every couple of weeks since then. It's got great replay value, and each update has brought more and more things to explore.

I am a particular fan of the writings of H.P. Lovecraft, and the game evokes a strong lovecraftian sense of horror, brought out even further by the text being presented in the style of a first person journal.

The theme of the game really draws you in and, from reading interviews, I saw that it was influenced by Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness, which I decided to pick up. It has a lot of powerful imagery, particularly in conjuring the sense of being utterly alone in the jungle, with just a thin barrier of trees between you and the incomprehensibly vast wilderness. That detachment from civilisation comes through incredibly well in The Curious Expedition, especially in the descriptions of the campsite at night - the alien sounds, the foreign smells, the endless darkness - it all serves to immerse you in that unfamiliar world.

I highly recommend this game to all who will listen, and I look forward to discovering all the secrets in the updates to come.

First, let me tell you a story - a story about a nun. She accompanied me from the very beginning. Why? I have no clue. But I let her stay. On my second mission, I came across an unknown fluid in a temple. I didn't like my nun very much since she was sexist, a nun, and pretty useless for the most part, so I told her to drink it. She didn't hesitate and gulped it down. Her hands then transformed into claws - and although she probably didn't like it, it was the best thing that could have happened to me. With her beast claws she tore apart panthers, gorillas and even a tiger for me. She was a walking menace, following my orders. She also became an acloholic because of all the whiskey I forced her to drink in my effort to keep her sane. By the end of the fifth mission she was the most important member of my team, next to the water buffalo. On my last mission I went into a cave without a torch. It was pitch black. Suddenly the nun was gone and in her place was an abomination. Did she transform? Was she eaten? We weren't sure. The abomination was still cool since it also followed us around and was a good fighter, too. But one night, it started eating my soldier and I had to put it down. We had to go home without the nun. She almost made it to the end. We only got as far as we did because of her. This is for the nun whom I disrespected, whose name I've already forgotten, but whose claws I'll never forget. You rocked.

Okay, storytime's over. This game is a historically almost accurate representation of the British Museum's history. It's the 1800's, archeology and exploration are en vogue. You are a famous person of your choice, you travel to a wild, unexplored part of the planet of your choice and then proceed to rob the people there of as much cultural property as you can - and hope you'll get away with it. Steal from temples, kill wildlife, trade with villagers and/or slavers, catch butterflies; all that and more for fame, money and the British Museum.
The maps and events are randomly generated to guarantee a high replay value. You can manage your party and your inventory, both with solid mechanics and lots of choices. The battles are dice-based and strike a very nice balance between strategy and luck. Even though the game is still in early access, it feels pretty finished for the most part and the devs have delivered a good amount of updates over the last couple of months.

Verdict: A good game, definitely worth a try.

Even at this stage of development it is very playable with a lot of interesting and different mechanics. It is very heavy on storytelling, and each expedition tells a new tale. The graphics and animations are also very cute. And the devs are very friendly and active in the community, very communicative about their plans, and frequently implement ideas and comments from community discussions - and I've only been following this a couple of weeks. To boot, the game has a darkly humourous streak, while at the same time managing to make incisive commentary on the very negative effects that colonial exploration and expansion had on the rest of the world.

To avoid potential disappointment I should just comment on the Early Access status of the game. Mechanically and structurally there is a whole lot of stuff in there but currently the content isn't anything like as fleshed out within that as it will eventually be. The Early Access period is being extended somewhat indefinitely so long as they can afford to keep adding comment, and the devs have indicated they want to carry on until around the end of the year. So given they are currently releasing pretty feature-packed updates every couple of weeks, there is an absolute ton of stuff still to come.

Finally - Charles Darwin riding a velociraptor, legging it from a tear in the fabric of space-time consuming the entire map, of course not forgetting to continue gathering rare butterflies with his butterfly net on the way. Enough said!

The Curious Expedition is yet another Kickstarter-spawned entry into the ever-growing field of Rogue-Likes, but with a refreshing new twist. This time around, the player takes on the role of a small party of 19th-Century explorers engaged in a gentleman's wager - to travel the world on six concurrent expeditions, competing to see who can gain the most fame. To win the game you need to finish 6 expeditions while competing for fame against 4 other AI controlled adventurers. Each character comes with its own particular set of skills and abilities to help aid your journey.

Along with your character you’ll have some friends to accompany you. Keep an eye on their status though…they could easily turn into raging alcoholic cannibalistic kleptomaniacs, which can put your trek in great danger! Alas, to actually finish an expedition you have to reach the beloved golden pyramid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’m ever the cynic when it comes to early access titles, often to the point of barring me from purchasing one. The setting/genre niche The Curious Expedition filled made me initially change my tune, but alas, perhaps I should have been more discerning. My excitement for the setting clouded my judgment.

As of writing this review, I’ve logged 7-8 hours, and while I enjoy the game, I’ve run across a few bugs and headaches here and there. For about a third or quarter of my games, when the game doesn’t lag, it freezes, and when it doesn’t freeze, it crashes, and occasionally combat will bug where the enemy party or your own will do no damage. New party members can’t be analyzed, forcing the player to remember two dozen die faces and traits or hope for the best with their new compatriots, and certain mechanics, such as a party member fleeing (which often results in the theft of an item), forfeit necessary questing items, rendering maps unwinnable. Combat demands better explanation, I was forced to browse the community hub for a guide I'd call plastic at best. That being said, these, to me, are minor issues, and if the developer is perceptive enough, certain to be remedied in the final launch.

The above are not enough to net the negative review, however. Rather than the alpha state quirks, it seems woefully implemented game features are to blame. The game has no concept of difficulty scaling, with some initial starter expeditions wiping a party while other 4th or 5th expeditions being a 20 day affair (to give you an idea of the pace, a ‘race type mission’ wants you to complete the expedition in 80 days, psshaw). The character line-up is as lacking as its difficulty in more ways than one, insofar as some characters’ equipment and party members are so lacking as to render them nearly unplayable, while others seem carbon-copies with only a utility or two of difference. Additionally, the character line up, while not entirely mechanically-inhibiting, is, dare I say it, curious? The likes of Nikola Tesla and Ada Lovelace populate the roster of an exploration title that hints at the Vernian, so I’m uncertain if this was a developer’s fetishizing some of their personal idols or a vapid attempt to gain so-called ‘geek cred’.

The game needs work, and while it remains a good time kill (each game can probably be completed in under an hour), I wouldn’t have paid what I did, despite the sale, had I watched a let’s play first. I’ll be certain to be more careful in the future. Caveat Emptor.

Early Access Review

Previewers Note: Most of my playtime hasn't been logged due to playing in offline mode. I will be playing more and eventually be reviewing the title upon it's full realese but here's a preview.

When going on an expedition, you'd normally expect the story to start off with hardened adventurers off to explore new lands. You probably don't expect someone like Marie Curie, Harriett Tubman or Nikola Tesla going on these expeditions, but this isn't any expedition; it's an expedition in the game The Curious Expedition. Published and developed by Maschinen-Mensch, The Curious Expedition is a pixel art-styled exploration game with dice rolling combat and RPG elements, and it's now on Steam Early Access. It's an odd little game that can't be recommended to everyone, but for those who enjoy quirky little strategy games, this game is for you.

A curious thing about The Curious Expedition is the fact that there is no real “good guys” or “bad guys” like you'd see in something like, say, Tomb Raider or The Uncharted series. Yes, you do need to beat your competition, but they aren't necessarily bad people, they're just people you're competing against to make the most money. The game is rather amoral, which is a delightful change of pace considering how black and white a game like this could potentially be if given in the hands of the wrong developer. However, The Curious Expedition takes it to a different level and makes your actions affect your party members in different ways, making their general rapport with you, however basic a few lines of dialogue can be, completely different.

This game is nice for what it is. A quick 10 or 15 min exploration/semi-survival game with really nice retro graphics.

You have 6 missions per game. So basically an hour, maybe slightly longer per game. Perma death so if you die you have to start over.

With the above in mind, on the first few missions you cant even recruit/aquire lizardmen companions or raptor pets. You arent given enough game time to actually use and be able to enjoy anything youve earned or bought. Sometimes your companions just up and die for no reason, or get angry and leave for reasons that make absolutely no sense.

The game worlds/areas you explore, are kinda nice....unless your actually trying to explore. Mountians and chasims often block your way from your objective.

Combat is merely a random number generator. For me some times my die always worked out, and sometimes they didnt work at all. Enemy dice seem to always hit.

I did several play throughs on this game, and maby Im just a terrible explorer, but I never finished higher that 4th place. The AI explorers you compete against complete their missions extremely fast. And they seem to be rewarded with points on a completely different system than you are.

Also during your explorations youll find trinkets and artifacts to bring back. You have to choose to either sell them for money, donate them for fame or keep them. Well....you cant keep them because they take up space and are really worthless to trade with villagers, selling them is nice but most items are only worth 10 or 20 so you dont earn much money, and buying items for your next trip is expensive. Donations are worse than selling. reason being is that the AI explorers have so much fame that donating isnt enough to keep up with them.

I know all about the EA arguement but these devs really seem to be finished with the base game. And that is a shame. I like the idea this game has, but its implimentation is more of a hassle then anything. Its hard to enjoy the things you earn in this game when you only have it for 15 mins.

I cant reccomend this game, not for $15. Buy it on sale if you really want to try it. Developers will only look at how many positive reviews they have and then wear a grin all the way to the bank.

This game is NOT worth $15. What a shame.

Do you feel lucky?
No, really, do you? Because the answer to that question is, incidentally, also the answer to whether you would enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cannot recommend this game.  This game reminds me of a slot machine.  While it technically requires your input, it is almost entirely luck based.  And like playing the lottery, your chances of winning are extremely slim.  Perhaps the game’s one true quality is that, like a slot machine, it is very addictive.  Every time you lose, you feel the urge to play the game again; hoping this time you’ll have better luck.  And luck is what it’s all about.  There is a dice role behind almost every facet of this game.  Who will you have the opportunity to recruit?  Will you get swallowed up in growing pit as you try to run away?  Will you randomly walk towards the temple, or will it be placed in the most remote region of the map?  The game is not entirely luck, however luck plays an overwhelming role in your success or failure.  There are some choices you can make which are clearly better than others.  For example, an abomination is a great addition to your party.  However, you have to be lucky enough to stumble upon a scroll of abomination before you have the opportunity to make that decision.  If you are lucky enough to recruit a strong party, you might choose to attack animals as a way to make money.

Combat is this game’s one strength.  Like a game of poker, the combat combines strategy with elements of luck.  Unfortunately, strategy does not play a significant role in other aspects of the game.  You can make all the best decisions and still lose over and over again.

If you want to know what playing Curious Expedition is like, and don’t want to spend any money, try to get a coin to land heads-up twenty times in a row.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely brilliant concept, that has been implemented very well. Lead a team of intrepid explorers on increasingly difficult expeditions, as they battle everything from giant gorillas to mummies. Their greatest adversary, however, is not the beasts, but their own sanity. As they penetrate ever deeper into the dense jungles or barren deserts, their minds deteriorate. When you run out of water, machetes, and similar tools required to cope with the climate and terrain, the process accelerates. This is when hilarity ensues as the dark humour starts to shine through in earnest. Redcoats with drinking problems may turn into paranoid cannibals, reckless use of ancient spells may transform the most trusty follower into a flesh-eating abomination, and one by one your expedition will succumb to the madness.

Anyone with even a vague appreciation for tongue-in-cheek 19th century-style exploration (i.e. plundering), the Indiana Jones movies and/or Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness (or Coppola's Apocalypse Now for that matter) will find plenty of amusing references to chuckle over.

In gameplay terms, it's a pretty classic roguelike, with plenty of similarities with FTL. The combat system is easy enough to grasp once you've learned the basics (combos are key, as are balancing defensive and offensive moves), but deep enough to keep you entertained. It's challenging, but not absurdly difficult (unlike many other roguelikes), with a high replayability value.

I tip my jungle helmet to the devs, and thrust myself into the jungle once more. Just one more expedition...

reviewText:

So my most recent campaign something amazing happened: I found a dinosaur skull on my third expedition! When I returned to London that unlocked a special area for my fourth expedition: an area secreted in a volcano shell in North America! I had been mercilessly hunting every wild animal in sight and was loaded with funds from selling the pelts, so I stocked up and ventured forth!
A few days into the journey my expedition came upon 2 Raptors! They proved no match for my guns and advanced tactics and I harvested their skins and feasted on their meat. It was delicious. A month later I found a raptor hatching ground, with a live egg! I took it with me, expecting to sell it back in London for a fortune. Shortly after this something strange happened, even by the standards of a prehistoric expedition! I found a village, not of humans, but of Lizard People! Luckily I was skilled with languages and was able to communicate with the natives. When I asked if any would wish to accompany me I was offered the service of a dinosaur! The Chasmosaur put my Donkey to shame with it's ability to carry my gear, so I left the Donkey to find its way in this strange land and continued on. After several fights with other Raptors and Giant Birds my egg hatched, a tiny Velociraptor had emerged! Of course I kept the little thing with us and carried on. Shortly after that we found the Golden Temple and made our triumphant return to England.
With the treasures I had accumulated in that wonderful land I became famous and wealthy beyond imagining! I upgraded the already impressive carrying capacity of my Chasmosaur, stocked up on tons of supplies, and decided to explore another prehistoric location. This time I was in Australia and everything proceeded as before, when my Raptor was fully grown I dismissed my Sailor, over the protestations of my Cook and Soldier, and made room for my new scaly friend. Mounted upon his back we progressed! Everything seemed to be going so well, until I came to a Shrine. I was familiar with the normal traps in these structures and foolishly decided to loot it before sufficiently exploring the area. We barely managed to outrun the lake that spread across the entire region, but worst of all when the dust cleared I was stranded! Barely a few parcels of land surrounded by impassable mountains and depthless lakes! I was forced to construct a balloon and leave most of the treasure, including what I had looted from the shrine, behind as my companions and I escaped back to London. My rivals successful expeditions allowed them catch up, and in some cases surpass, my fame.
Undaunted I prepared for the sixth, and final, expedition. There was only one choice that could cement my victory, a primeval location in Africa. Having spent most of my funds on the previous expedition I was forced to make do with what little I could still afford, although I was lucky to retain the services of all my companions. We set sail, more determined than ever. After the voyage we immediately saw a pair of Raptor packs patrolling the area, and decided that the best course of action was to stock up on food and trade supplies by righting these creatures. We were successful and had begun to rebuild our stock of supplies. After several months of adventuring, finding keystones and activating mysterious shrines, we had a good stock of supplies, having encountered a brave, wandering merchant several weeks past. Eventually we came upon another shrine, having been unsuccessful in my previous expedition I knew that to truly win this competition I needed the golden treasures, valued greatly by the Explorer's Society, hidden within. I put more effort into preparing this time, clearing out all I needed from the surrounding area before venturing into the forbidden shrine. Inside we went, and two gold idols were inside! I grabbed them and we ran, a vast chasm opened up behind us, yet still we ran, until a mountain showed my lack of planning, slowing us down. The chasm opened beneath our feet and that was the last anyone saw of us.
...




10/10 Would die again.
A thoroughly challenging and amazingly fun game. The above was my fourth campaign (although I have watched several LPs of earlier builds), and despite my last minute death, with victory tauntingly close, I was still enthralled. The last game I felt this way about was FTL, and in many ways Curious Expedition reminds me of FTL. You build up your expedition crew, manage inventories, decide how to proceed. If you like rogue-likes, enjoyed FTL, or just have 15$ to spare, I HIHGLY recommend this game.
Even though it says Early Access the game is very polished, only a few small bugs, and some balance issues, remain. Honestly I would be happy with the game if they stopped development now, so if they keep improving it (and they've said they plan to!) then I will be one happy camper.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Best early access game that I've played.
Hands down.

Worth the $15 it costs even at this early stage. I admit though that I am positively biased toward a game with its theme on exploration during the 1800s. Nonetheless, here's the breakdown (possible spoilers?):

Graphics (8/10):
In no way are the graphics anything to brag about, but that's part of The Curious Expedition's charm (and common among Rogue-like adventure games). The characters, landscapes, and backgrounds are quite colorful and it is fun to see such charming sprites wiggle across the dangerous terrain. The ease on processors is a bonus as well.

Audio (6/10):
The music is enjoyable and sets the atmosphere for the time period quite well. Although, the tracks are short (specifically in the menu and pre-exploration areas) and I found myself a little disengaged when they would abruptly stop and start again.

Gameplay (10/10):
I am negatively biased toward Rogue-like games as I pretty much suck at them, so this particular rating should speak volumes. In no way is this an easy game (I died countless times), but I found myself emersed in the game, not realizing that 8 hours had passed the first session I played it.
Decisions are made through simple point-and-click gameplay, though they are almost always consequence-based decisions: choosing an explorer, each with their own set of perks, companions, and gear; choosing how to deal with natives and their sacred places and objects; deciding what to do with unruly companions, what items to keep or leave behind, and what possibly rewarding objects to hold on to or use for its unique and magical benefit; finally, the most punishing decisions being which way to travel, and, seeing as it costs sanity, making mistakes can cause loss of party members, gear, eventually fame and forutne, and even the expedition itself.
Other than the decision-based part of the game, there is dice-based combat against beasts and angry natives. There are three types of dice (attack, defense, and support), the amount of which is determined by party member skills and abilities, and combining them in different ways produces different results for damaging your opponent or blocking your opponent's attacks. Personally, I like a simple system with complex results, which is exactly what this combat system is.

Story (7/10):
The story is simple as you play the part of an explorer seeking fame and fortune in the wilder parts of the world. The story changes with every playthrough as the events that the explorer goes through actually make up the story itself. Other than that, there is almost no story, but this doesn't take away from the game as much as actually add to it. Because your unique actions per playthrough create a unique story each time, the narrative relies on the player, and therefore makes for exciting expectations. A post-adventure transcription of the events of each expedition is desirable though.

Replayability (10/10):
I have played it over and over, each time having a different experiance. The maps seem to be randomly generated and each encounter has many different possible outcomes. It took many playthroughs just to beat it (finally!) and I don't expect the next time I beat it to be any time soon or in anyway the same as the first time. I will say that there are a few difficulties that can be avoided once you get over the games learning curve and pick up a few tricks, therefore making later playthroughs a bit easier, although this doesn't take any enjoyment away from the game, in fact making it more enjoyable knowing that you are using your newfound skills and being rewarded for it. On top of that, there is replayability in: beating the game with each character, making different choices for encounters you've had before just to see the outcome, and not just beating the game but getting 1st place in fame among your fellow explorers.
Total: 8.2/10
Noteable Mentions:
Canniblism
Abominations
Being a d*ck to natives
Dinosaurs in the 1800s
Nikola Tesla and his Tesla Gun
Selling your companions into slavery
A Giant Tortoise you can raise as a pet from birth
Blackholes as punishment for taking treasure that you shouldn't've

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely brilliant concept, that has been implemented very well. Lead a team of intrepid explorers on increasingly difficult expeditions, as they battle everything from giant gorillas to mummies. Their greatest adversary, however, is not the beasts, but their own sanity. As they penetrate ever deeper into the dense jungles or barren deserts, their minds deteriorate. When you run out of water, machetes, and similar tools required to cope with the climate and terrain, the process accelerates. This is when hilarity ensues as the dark humour starts to shine through in earnest. Redcoats with drinking problems may turn into paranoid cannibals, reckless use of ancient spells may transform the most trusty follower into a flesh-eating abomination, and one by one your expedition will succumb to the madness.

Anyone with even a vague appreciation for tongue-in-cheek 19th century-style exploration (i.e. plundering), the Indiana Jones movies and/or Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness (or Coppola's Apocalypse Now for that matter) will find plenty of amusing references to chuckle over.

In gameplay terms, it's a pretty classic roguelike, with plenty of similarities with FTL. The combat system is easy enough to grasp once you've learned the basics (combos are key, as are balancing defensive and offensive moves), but deep enough to keep you entertained. It's challenging, but not absurdly difficult (unlike many other roguelikes), with a high replayability value.

I tip my jungle helmet to the devs, and thrust myself into the jungle once more. Just one more expedition...
